Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Changes in river-aquifer exchange induced by groundwater pumping, and their effect on arsenic contamination in the Red River Delta, Vietnam
Award.AbstractNarration:
Collaborative Research: Changes in river-aquifer exchange induced by groundwater pumping and their effect on arsenic contamination in the Red River Delta, Vietnam

Abstract

At least two billion people in the world, including an estimated 40 million in the United States, use domestic wells for potable drinking water. The quality of this groundwater can have a large impact on human health, yet we know little about how extensive groundwater pumping, primarily for agricultural and urban water supplies, impacts groundwater quality. This project studies the effect of groundwater pumping on the sustainability of water quality in aquifer systems affected by arsenic, a naturally occurring carcinogen. In South and Southeast Asia, extensive pumping has influenced the spatial extent and concentration of arsenic contamination in groundwater. This field-based project examines how hydrological changes impact the biogeochemistry of aquifers and, subsequently, the arsenic levels in groundwater. Specifically, this project investigates how urban water use in Vietnam is changing aquifer hydrology and river-groundwater interactions that mobilize arsenic. The results of this study will provide generalizable insights leading to more effective management of groundwater resources impacted by naturally occurring contaminants in other settings. The research activities will involve undergraduate and graduate students from Columbia University, Barnard College, and Massachusetts Institute of Technology and engage underprivileged high school students in New York City.

In northern Vietnam, the reversal of groundwater flow along the western bank of the Red River has been induced by groundwater pumping for the city of Hanoi. This flow reversal draws high-As groundwater from a gray Holocene aquifer into an adjacent low arsenic, orange Pleistocene aquifer, and the orange Pleistocene sands are turning gray as iron oxyhydroxides are reduced by advected dissolved organic carbon (DOC). This project examines how pumping influences the source and composition of aquifer recharge at the riverbank, where labile arsenic is available and high levels of DOC are released by freshly deposited sediments. To quantify the impact of urban pumping, the hydrology and biogeochemistry of the western bank aquifers of the Red River influenced by pumping are compared to the eastern bank aquifers that are insulated from the effects of pumping. This controlled study quantifies the extent to which human perturbations have affected the chemical composition of groundwater and aquifer sediments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Throughout rural South and Southeast Asia, several hundred million people rely on domestic wells for drinking water. The quality of this groundwater is critical, yet we know little about how extensive groundwater pumping for large cities and growing rice has influenced the spatial extent and concentration of arsenic, a major contaminant affecting the region. In the absence of pumping, groundwater typically flows into rivers because precipitation exceeds evaporation in these humid regions. In northern Vietnam, we documented the reversal of this groundwater flow induced by groundwater pumping for the city of Hanoi along the western bank of the Red River. We have shown that this flow reversal draws high-As groundwater from a gray Holocene aquifer into an adjacent low-As, orange Pleistocene aquifer and that the orange Pleistocene sands is turning grey as iron oxyhydroxides are reduced by advected dissolved organic carbon (DOC).  Our work combined a wide range of field measurements (groundwater chemistry, water levels in wells, microbiological characterization, aquifer mineralogy) with computer models of processes that cause groundwater contamination and transport contaminants in flowing groundwater.

We established that reactive carbon is being advected into the aquifer from rivers, and other sources, as a result of groundwater pumping.  We examined carbon utilization by pairing measurements of the radiocarbon ages of DOC, sediment and methane with the radiocarbon ages of DNA or RNA from microbes in the aquifer, which has the same age as the substrate(s) that they utilize. These experiments show that the organic carbon used is primarily young (relative to sediments) and thus must be advected from shallow depths.  In parallel, we have been examining the biological communities in these aquifers directly using genomics and metagenomic approaches. Those investigations reveal dynamic changes in microbial abundance and activity across the transect. The most significant finding is that iron reducing bacteria are generally not dominant, and instead there are mixtures of sulfide oxidizers and methane oxidizers most prevalent in zones of extensive iron reduction. This unexpected result supports our hypothesis that methane oxidation may drive iron reduction, suggesting that iron reduction may not be as simple as assumed in many of the places where it is believed to cause arsenic contamination.

We established that different recharge sources appear to carry different levels of organic carbon, and arsenic, into the aquifer from the surface.  We traced recharge sources with natural geochemical tracers (δ2H, δ18O and chloride/bromide ratios) in the Hanoi region of the Red River Delta. We find overall, that groundwaters not derived from the river have the expected relationships that higher DOC (leading to more reduction) correlates with higher As. In zones where groundwater still discharges to the river, however, high aquifer As concentrations appear to be inversely correlated with DOC levels, suggesting that either the DOC is more reactive in these areas, or that the recharge waters already contain substantial As. Thus, surface water-groundwater interactions appear to be critical in regulating water quality.
